The Tens
The First Chapter
The Elder Upasena, the Son of Vaṅganta
Alone, with little noise,
frequented by wild beasts and deer,
A monk should frequent a dwelling place
for the sake of seclusion.
Having brought together a heap of rubbish
from the charnel ground and the roads,
Then having made a patchwork robe,
he should wear a coarse robe.
Having made his mind humble,
from house to house in due order,
A monk should wander for alms,
his sense doors guarded, well-restrained.

original: Lūkhenapi vā santusse,🔽nāññaṁ patthe rasaṁ bahuṁ;
analyzed: lūkhena api vā  na aññam patthe rasam bahu
translated: Even if satisfied with coarse (alms),🔽he should not seek other, more tasty (alms);
The mind of one who is greedy for tastes
does not delight in jhāna.
One who is content with little,
a sage should live secluded;
Not associating with householders
or with those gone forth on both sides.

original: Yathā jaḷo va mūgo va,🔽attānaṁ dassaye tathā;
analyzed: yathā jaḷaḥ mūgaḥ  attānam dassaye tathā
translated: As if he were dumb or mute,🔽so should he show himself;
The wise one should not speak too much
in the midst of the Saṅgha.
He should not find fault with anyone,
he should avoid doing harm;
Restrained in the Pāṭimokkha,
and know the right amount in eating.
One who has well-taken the sign,
skilled in the arising of consciousness,
should apply himself to serenity
and to insight in due course.
Endowed with energy and mindfulness,
one should always be devoted to meditation;
without reaching the end of suffering,
the wise one should not be confident.
Dwelling in this way,
for the monk who desires purity,
all the pollutants are destroyed,
and he attains Nibbāna.”
… the elder Upasena Vaṅgantaputta …
